main.name: Mae Zhang
main.description: I'm an undergraduate student at Carnegie Mellon University, expected to graduate in 2023. Learn more about me and my projects here!
main.bio: I am an adventurous nerd who likes to learn and explore new things. As an engineer, I strive to not only produce solutions, but also continue to improve them as I push my own boundaries. In my free time, I love to solve puzzles, play board games, and hike.

education.degree: Bachelors in Electrical and Computer Engineering
education.description: CMU provides opportunity for me to grow in many aspects of my life. My experiences thus far have strengthened my passion and proficiency in programming and allowed me to explore hardware for the first time with hands-on experience. Outside of academia, I indulge in puzzle-solving as a member of Puzzlehunt, build buggies for CIA Buggy, and waltz across the dance floor in Ballroom Dance Club.

I am lucky to have been in an environment where students are actively engaged in learning and their community. Through debating with my peers, competing in intense math competitions, and creating fond memories as the Percussion Captain of my marching band, I transitioned into a more confident and open-minded individual.

work.title: Programming Intern
work.description: SupportChef is a drag and drop app builder whose content can be integrated into an existing app. Using JavaScript, ReactJS, CSS, and other libraries, I developed many front end features such as the styling page where users can customize their appâ€™s colors and fonts and the responses page where users can see all the data that was submitted through their app. This experience sparked a profound interest in website development for me, as it allowed me to fully appreciate the process of creating a website and the user interface of the finished product.

work.title: Research Intern
work.description: NRF2 is a transcription factor that reduces oxidative stress in healthy cells but was found to promote chemoresistance in cancer cells. Our goal at the Chapman lab was to produce potential compounds to inhibit the transcription factor NRF2 to increase the effects of chemotherapy. I implemented purification techniques such as thin layer chromatography and column chromatography to create such compounds that would be potent enough to inhibit NRF2 on a large scale. I won 3rd place in Biochemistry at the Southern Arizona Research, Science, and Engineering Foundation competition and am a co-author of an American Chemical Society paper.
